abstract.text: A value type for a string with associated attributes for portions of its text.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Attributed strings are character strings that have attributes for individual characters or ranges of characters. Attributes provide traits like visual styles for display, accessibility for guided access, and hyperlink data for linking between data sources. Attribute keys provide the name and value type of each attribute. System frameworks like Foundation and SwiftUI define common keys, and you can define your own in custom extensions.
You can apply an attribute to an entire string, or to a range within the string. The string represents each range with consistent attributes as a
run
uses subscripts and dynamic member lookup to simplify working with attributes from your call points. In its most verbose form, you set an attribute by creating an
and merging it into an existing attributed string, like this:

code: var attributedString = AttributedString("This is a string with empty attributes.")

inlineContent.text: Using the attributed string’s
method, you can omit the explicit use of an
and just set the attribute by its type:
Because an
supports dynamic member lookup — as described under
in
— you can access its subscripts with dot syntax instead. When combined with properties like
that return the attribute key type, this final form offers a natural way to set an attribute that applies to an entire string:
This example works because AppKit defines an
, in which the property
returns the type
. Because AppKit’s attribute scope implements
, the dot syntax resolves to an equivalent subscript expression, allowing
to replace
You can also set an attribute to apply only to part of an attributed string, by applying the attribute to a range, as seen here:

code: var attributedString = AttributedString("The first month of your subscription is free.")

inlineContent.text: You can access portions of the string with unique combinations of attributes by iterating over the string’s
property.
You can define your own custom attributes by creating types that conform to
, and collecting them in an
. Custom keys should also extend
, so callers can use dot-syntax to access the attribute.
You can create an attributed string by passing a standard
or
instance that contains Markdown to initializers like
. The attributed string creates attributes by parsing the markup in the string.
Localized strings that you load from strings files with initializers like
can also contain Markdown to add styling. In addition, these localized attributed string initializers can apply the
attribute, which allows you to determine the range of replacement strings, whose order may vary between languages.
By declaring new attributes that conform to
, you can add attributes that you invoke by using Apple’s Markdown extension syntax:
. See the sample code project
for an example of creating custom attributes and using them with Markdown.
Localized attributed strings can also use the extension syntax to indicate parts of the string where the system can apply automatic grammar agreement. See the initializers that take a
parameter for examples of this extension syntax, as used with automatic grammar agreement.
The
API defines keys for common uses, such as text styling, semantically marking up formattable types like dates and numbers, and hyperlinking. You can find these in the
enumeration, which contains attributes for AppKit, Foundation, SwiftUI, and UIKit.

, and reference them by name by collecting them in an

abstract.text: A container for attribute keys and values.
A value type for a string with associated attributes for portions of its text.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether two values are not equal.
Concatenates two attributed strings.
Appends an attributed string to another attributed string.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether two attributed strings are equal.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether an attributed string and another attributed string or substring are equal.
Appends a string to the attributed string.
The characters of the attributed string, as a view into the underlying string.
A textual representation of the instance.
Encodes the value into the specified encoder, with help from the provided configuration.
Hashes the essential components of this value by feeding them into the given hasher.
The hash value.
Creates an empty attributed string.
Creates an attributed string from an attributed substring.
Creates an attributed string from a string and an attribute container.
Creates an attributed string from a substring and an attribute container.
Creates an attributed string from a character sequence and an attribute container.
Creates a value-type attributed string from a reference type, including an attribute scope.
Creates an instance initialized to the given value.
Creates a new instance by decoding from the specified decoder, with help from the provided configuration.
Creates an attributed string from the specified string literal, with no attributes.
Creates an instance initialized to the given value.
Inserts the specified string at a specific index in the attributed string.
Removes a range of characters from the attributed string.
Replaces occurrences of attributes in one attribute container with those in another attribute container.
Replaces the contents in a range of the attributed string.
The attributed runs of the attributed string, as a view into the underlying string.
Sets the attributed string’s attributes to those in a specified attribute container.
Returns an attributed string by setting the attributed string’s attributes to those in a specified attribute container.
Returns an attribute value that corresponds to an attributed string key.
Returns a substring of the attributed string using a range to indicate the substring bounds.
Returns an attribute value that a key path indicates.
Returns a scoped attribute container that a key path indicates.
Returns an attributed string by calling a closure that transforms one attribute, which a key path identifies, of a source attributed string.
Returns an attributed string created by calling a closure that transforms two attributes, which key paths identify, of a source attributed string.

abstract.text: An enumeration of behaviors to apply when merging attributes.
A view into the underlying storage of the attributed string, as Unicode characters.
The configuration type for decoding attributed strings.
Protocols adopted by attribute keys to encode or decode data.

abstract.text: The configuration type for encoding attributed strings.
The type that extended grapheme cluster literal initializers use.
Options that affect the handling of attributes.
A type that represents the position of a character or code unit within an attributed string.
Use a Markdown-syntax string to iniitalize an attributed string with standard or custom attributes.

abstract.text: Options that affect the behavior of string interpolation on the attributed string.
Configuration options for the localization of text.
An iterable view into segments of the attributed string, each of which indicates where a run of identical attributes begins or ends.
A type that transforms an attribute by altering its range or value, or by replacing it entirely.
The type that string literal initializers use.
The type that Unicode scalar literal initializers use.
A view into the underlying storage of the attributed string, as Unicode scalars.
A protocol that defines in-place mutations for attributes in an attributed string.
A portion of an attributed string.
A type to support dynamic member lookup of attributes and containers.
A configuration type for encoding and decoding attributed strings.
Collections of attributes that system frameworks define.
A reference to a localizable string, accessible from another process.
A string of text that manages data, layout, and stylistic information for ranges of characters to support rendering.
A mutable string with associated attributes (such as visual style, hyperlinks, or accessibility data) for portions of its text.
An attribute container that allows dynamic member lookup of its contents within the specified attribute scope.
Types that the attributed string, attributed substring, and helper types extend or conform to, for sharing common functionality.
A reference to a localizable string, with optional string interpolation.
